stream_context.summary: Kaze livestreams level-building work on the overworld for “Return to Yoshi’s Island,” finishing first-pass art on the first four overworld sub-areas, iterating textures, mountain shapes, caves, and puzzle ideas while chatting about beta testing, finances, and design philosophy.

development_findings.summary: Overall overworld progress is about 30 %; the overworld is split into 14 parts and the first four parts are now art-complete after this stream.
development_findings.quote: I would say overworld 28 %, and… course 6 ? 10 %. We finished the first four parts and there’s 14 parts here in total.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is polishing rather than blocking new content; the game could technically release now but he has not imposed a hard polishing cutoff.
development_findings.quote: We’re almost in a state where we would be able to just release the game, but there is still some polishing I want to do and there isn’t really a limit I set myself.

development_findings.summary: New star concept for Course 3 cave: multiple crystals placed on platforms; while Mario holds one, a hidden path appears around him and only exists during possession.
development_findings.quote: The idea was there would be a crystal here and while you hold the crystal a path around Mario appears and you can only attack with the path while you are holding the crystal.

development_findings.summary: Design goal to reduce punishment for falling into the cave water by adding small recovery platforms and shortcuts instead of forcing long swims.
development_findings.quote: How do I make falling in here suck less? … a bunch of tiny platforms that you can jump on to get back to the beginning sounds perfect.

development_findings.summary: Implementation of a one-way mirror between overworld and Course 3 so players can see into the level from the hub and experience a reflection from inside the course.
development_findings.quote: In Course 3 there is this mirror… then in the overworld there is this where you can look through the mirror. Basically it’s like a one-way mirror into the level.

development_findings.summary: A fast64 engine bug causes water splash color mismatches; Kaze is waiting for upstream fix rather than diverting time to it now.
development_findings.quote: Nope, that’s still a bug in Fast 64, not much I can do about it. I can just wait for them to fix it.

development_findings.summary: Beta testing phase focuses on casual play-through feedback, not bug hunting; testers recruited via Google Form, avoiding Patreon for legal safety.
development_findings.quote: The beta testing here is literally just you casually playing the game… I don’t want to get into any legal trouble here, so I don’t want to look for testers on Patreon.

development_findings.summary: Biobak finished Course 2 and is re-texturing Course 3; Kaze defers color-tuning to him and expects progress tracker update soon.
development_findings.quote: I think Biobak also finished Course 2… he said he would update the progress tracker… it’s gotta be done by now.

development_findings.summary: Future visual tasks include adding water reflections, adjusting dirt and grass textures, and creating lightmaps around crystals.
Kaze plans to leave performance issues like splash colors or N64 brightness for later unless no one else patches them "for a really long time."

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s German tax situation is unresolved; his accountant is unresponsive, creating stress and financial uncertainty.
context_findings.quote: I paid them, but I am not 100 % certain that they know I paid them, and also the Finanzamt still has to send me back like four thousand dollars.

context_findings.summary: He increases YouTube video output primarily to earn income to "feed my family," relying on sponsorships such as Squarespace.
context_findings.quote: I need to make more videos because I need to feed my family. It sounds so depressing, but it is what it is.

context_findings.summary: Kaze refuses conversion-based sponsorship deals, insisting on flat-rate payments to avoid carrying product risk.
context_findings.quote: They offered a conversions-based thing or a flat rate. I said the only one I want is the flat rate… otherwise I’m taking on all the risk for your product.

context_findings.summary: Design philosophy: Mario hacks are easier than Zelda hacks because Nintendo already solved core movement fun; Zelda requires puzzle and story design, making hacks far harder.
context_findings.quote: When you make a Zelda hack you have to actually design the puzzles, the story, everything. It is so much harder to actually make a fun Zelda game than it is to make a fun Mario game.

context_findings.summary: He values rational debate and ‘Bayesian thinking,’ aiming for discussions where participants can admit being wrong.
context_findings.quote: This is actually something you will only see on this channel… at the end of the argument the person can be like, ‘Dang, I was wrong.’

biobak.summary: Finished Course 2 art and is reworking textures for Course 3; Kaze is waiting on his updated progress numbers.
biobak.quote: I think Biobak also finished Course 2… he finished the Course 3 rework.

biobak.summary: Will handle final color and texture adjustments, so Kaze leaves some visual tweaks for him.

key_stories.title: Recovering the Forgotten Star Idea
key_stories.summary: While detailing the cave, Kaze realizes he has forgotten the planned star mechanic. After searching old VODs and discussing with chat, Biobak reminds him and the concept is restored.
key_stories.challenge: Lost memory of how the Course 3 cave star was supposed to work.
key_stories.process: Scrolled through past streams and asked viewers; considered shelving cave until idea resurfaced; Biobak’s hint jogged memory.
key_stories.outcome: Re-established design: carry crystals that reveal a temporary path.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh, that’s the idea… there would be a crystal here and while you hold the crystal a path around Mario appears.

key_stories.title: Beta Tester Recruitment Without Legal Risk
key_stories.summary: Kaze needs casual gameplay feedback but wishes to avoid Nintendo scrutiny. He opens a Google Form invite and explicitly avoids Patreon recruitment to reduce legal exposure.
key_stories.challenge: Secure testers while minimizing legal vulnerability.
key_stories.process: Created Google Form; announced on stream; clarified expectations (casual play, early build).
key_stories.outcome: Community members receive first opportunity to join; larger call will follow if needed.
key_stories.key_quote: I don’t want to get into any legal trouble here, so I don’t want to look for testers on Patreon.

key_stories.title: The German Tax Ordeal
key_stories.summary: Living in Canada, Kaze struggles with Germany’s Finanzamt through an unresponsive accountant, leaving him uncertain about over-payments and refunds.
key_stories.challenge: Verify tax compliance and recover €4 k refund.
key_stories.process: Hired accountant; paid fees; attempted but failed to reach him by phone due to distance and cost.
key_stories.outcome: Issue remains unresolved, adding stress and motivating increased video output for income.
key_stories.key_quote: I think I did everything right but I have no proof for it, and there’s no way for me to find out.
